data.title: 22 Natural Wonders In India That Your Geography Teacher Forgot To Tell You About
data.meta_description: India doesn’t cease to amaze the world with its wonders – both man-made and natural. We present to you a list of 22 most amazing natural wonders of India.
data.text:
With a vast geographical range and an ever larger size, India doesn’t cease to amaze the world with its wonders – both man-made and natural. This land of wonders offers many unsolved and intriguing mysteries.

Here’s a list of 22 most amazing natural wonders of India that takes you through hills, rocks and caves; and leads to strangest of beaches and islands.

22 Natural Wonders In India

India is a land of endless opportunities when it comes to travel and exploring places. Let’s have a look at some of the natural wonders in India that will leave you spellbound by their charm.

Natural Arch, Tirumala hills: A Rocky Wonder Of India

Magnetic Hill, Ladakh: Illusion To Defy Gravity

Marble Rocks, Jabalpur: Soft Enough To Be Cut By Scapels

Balancing Rock, Mahabalipuram: The Precarious Boulder

Needle Hole Point, Mahabaleshwar: Naturally Crafted Elephant Trunk Hill

Nellitheertha Cave, Karnataka: Hiding The Lingam And Lake Within

Amarnath Cave, Jammu & Kashmir: The Iced Lingam Of Lord Shiva

Belum Caves, Andhra Pradesh: Longest Caves In Indian Sub-Continent

Borra Caves, Andhra Pradesh: Deepest Caves In India

Loktak Floating Lake, Manipur: Only Floating Lake In The World

Lonar Lake, Maharashtra: World’s Oldest Meteroric Crater Lake

Manikaran Natural Springs: Hot Water Bath In River Beas

Hide-and-Seek Beach, Orissa: Vanishing Beach Of Chandipur

Majuli Island, Assam: The Riverine Island In Brahmaputra

Living Root Twin Bridges, Meghalaya: The One-Odd Tree Wonder

Yana Caves, Karnataka: Pilgrim Place

Dudhsagar Falls, Goa: Rush Of Milk

Valley Of Flowers, Uttarakhand: Exotic Flowers

Great Rann of Kutch, Gujarat: White Salt Marshland

Reverse Waterfall, Lonavala: Waterfall That Flows Up

Hogenakkal, Tamil Nadu: Niagara Falls Of India

Krishna’s Butter Ball, Mahabalipuram: A Rare Phenomenon

1. Natural Arch, Tirumala hills: A Rocky Wonder Of India

Image Source

Located in the state of Andhra Pradesh, this 2.5 billion years old arch was formed due to natural erosive forces. The formation of the rocky wonder is attributed to the intensified weathering and erosion of stream action that has withstood the torque of nature.

Looking To Book A Holiday Package?

2. Magnetic Hill, Ladakh: Illusion To Defy Gravity

Image Source

Located in the celestial Ladakh valley, the Magnetic Hill defies gravity. Put your car in neutral on this hill and it will move upwards instead of downwards.

Must Read: 40 Most Amazing Places To Visit In India With Friends

3. Marble Rocks, Jabalpur: Soft Enough To Be Cut By Scapels

Image Source

The grand marble rocks at Bhedaghat near Jabalpur (Madhya Pradesh) are carved and cut by the flowing waters of the Narmada River. This exquisite beauty is about 3 km in length and soars to a 100 feet on both sides of the Narmada.

4. Balancing Rock, Mahabalipuram: The Precarious Boulder

Image Source

At the heritage-rich destination of Mahabalipuram, is the famous Balancing Rock. The massive rock stands on a slippery and tiny hill but has never lost balance.

Suggested Read: Top 17 Religious Places In India: Redefining Spirituality For Gen Y

5. Needle Hole Point, Mahabaleshwar: Naturally Crafted Elephant Trunk Hill

The Needle Hole Point/ Elephant Point in Mahabaleshwar offers a rare view of what seems like an elephant trunk crafted by a fine craftsman. But, as much as it is hard to believe, this Indian wonder has been formed by the forces of nature and nothing more.

Planning your holiday but confused about where to go? These travel stories help you find your best trip ever!

6. Nellitheertha Cave, Karnataka: Hiding The Lingam And Lake Within

Image Source

Wide in the beginning, this cave continues to become narrower as you go further inside. The visitors have to crawl through until it starts widening again. Inside the cave is a natural lingam of Lord Shiva and a lake. People often carry back with them the mud from the banks of the lake.

Suggested Read: 22 Natural Wonders In India That Your Geography Teacher Forgot To Tell You About

7. Amarnath Cave, Jammu & Kashmir: The Iced Lingam Of Lord Shiva

Image Source

Inarguably the holiest shrine in Hinduism, the Amarnath cave holds religious importance due to the formation of the mystical ice lingam of Lord Shiva. The freezing of water drops, which trickle down from the roof of the cave onto the floor beneath, leads to the formation of the natural stalagmite. This ice lingam waxes and wanes with the moon.

8. Belum Caves, Andhra Pradesh: Longest Caves In Indian Sub-Continent

Image Source

Located in Kurnool, Andhra Pradesh, Belum caves have been formed due to the continuous flow of underground water. These caves are the second largest caves in India and the longest in the plains of Indian sub-continent. In here are lengthy passages, airy chambers, fresh water galleries, and siphons.

Suggested Read: 19 Places To Visit In Yercaud That Uphold The True Essence Of South India

9. Borra Caves, Andhra Pradesh: Deepest Caves In India

Image Source

Located in the Ananthagiri Hills of the Araku Valley, Andhra Pradesh, the Borra Caves are the deepest caves in the country. The stalactites and stalagmites formed inside the cave are beautiful. The caves are also the home to bats, golden gecko, fulvous fruit bats, and insects.

10. Loktak Floating Lake, Manipur: Only Floating Lake In The World

Image Source

The only floating lake in the world and the largest freshwater lake in North-East India, Loktak Lake is rich in biodiversity. The habitat for 57 species of waterbirds and another 14 species of wetland-associated birds, this floating wonder is also the only home to the endangered sangai (brow-antlered deer).

Suggested Read: 10 Safe Places In India To Travel For A Care-Free Holiday Experience

11. Lonar Lake, Maharashtra: World’s Oldest Meteroric Crater Lake

Image Source

Located near Mehkar in Buldana of Maharashtra, the Lonar Crater Lake is the world’s oldest meteoric crater-lake and third largest in size. The crater dates back to approximately 50,000 years.

12. Manikaran Natural Springs: Hot Water Bath In River Beas

Image Source

Manikaran, a pilgrimage centre for both Hindus and Sikhs, is located in the Parvati Valley between the rivers Beas and Parvati, in Himachal Pradesh. Well known for its hot springs and beautiful landscapes, the gurudwara houses a hot water bath. Though not the only one in India, Manikaran has become extremely popular and a major tourist and pilgrim attraction.

13. Hide-and-Seek Beach, Orissa: Vanishing Beach Of Chandipur

Image Source

16 km from Balasore, Chandipur is a quiet beach on the Orissan coast. Counted as one of the most unique experiences of the world, the sea water here recedes about 5 km during low tide and advances to the shoreline again during high tide, each day.

Suggested Read: 29 Famous Lakes In India That Will Bedazzle You With Their Stunning Beauty

14. Majuli Island, Assam: The Riverine Island In Brahmaputra

Image Source

One of the largest riverine islands, Majuli Island lies in the river Brahmaputra in Assam. A hotspot for flora and fauna, the island is home to many endangered avifauna species.

15. Living Root Twin Bridges, Meghalaya: The One-Odd Tree Wonder

Image Source

These twin-living-root-bridges, located close to Cherrapunji in Meghalaya, offer an unbelievable sight. The roots of the ‘Ficus Elastica’ tree extend up to 3000 feet. They form a twin layer that the locals have been using as bridges over the river.

Suggested Read: Top 9 Waterfalls In North East India That Should Be On Your Bucket List

16. Yana Caves, Karnataka: Pilgrim Place

Image Source

Yana is a hill station located in North Karnataka which is known for its unparalleled beauty and scenic views. It is one of the best places for trekkers as the beauty of this place is enough to attract you and keep you here. But that is not all it is famous for. Yana also houses Yana caves, a famous attraction, an adventurous place, and centre of wildlife. This is one of the best getaway destinations. The greenery and freshness of the place coupled with two gigantic limestone monoliths attracts a large number of pilgrims around the year. The place not only holds a religious importance but is also a great place to trek and watch birds while relaxing in the lap of nature.

17. Dudhsagar Falls, Goa: Rush Of Milk

Image Source

Dudhsagar falls in Goa, a place that is known for its beautiful beaches, sunny skies, and playful waves, is a huge change in scenery. The place lies on the Goa – Karnataka border, about 60 kms from Panaji and is one of the best places to visit in Goa. Located inside the Mellem National Park, the lush green forest around the waterfall is a gorgeous beauty. Dudhsagar waterfall is counted amongst the highest waterfalls in the country and one of the hundred highest waterfalls in the world. The fall resembles a rush of milk, hence the name; Dudhsagar falls. The cold breeze, endless flow of white water, and the sound of water hitting the rocks will captivate you.

18. Valley Of Flowers, Uttarakhand: Exotic Flowers

Image Source

Valley of Flowers is exactly what it sounds like; a valley that is full of gorgeous and blooming flowers. Located in the Chamoli district of Uttarakhand, the place graces the Western Himalayas with its grace and beauty. Discovered in 1931, valley of flowers is a World Heritage Site which is known for its beautiful blooms and white peaks. The valley is filled with exotic varieties of flowers and medicinal herbs making it a perfect place to relax, laze around, and take in the beauty of the place.

19. Great Rann of Kutch, Gujarat: White Salt Marshland

Image Source

Located in the District of Kutch in Gujarat, Great Rann of Kutch is a large area of salt marshland that is situated in the Thar Desert. The salt marsh creates an amazing view that attracts tourists around the world. The sunsets here paint quite a picture that is worth every moment of being here. Watching the full moon in the surroundings will put you in a state of ecstacy.

20. Reverse Waterfall, Lonavala: Waterfall That Flows Up

Reverse waterfall in Lonavala is a phenomenon you cannot miss. If you are in Lonavala, trek your way through the Lohagad fort to this amazingly beautiful phenomenon. During monsoon, the waterfall fight against the gravity and goes back upwards owing to the high pressure winds making this an amazing place to visit and see the wonders of nature first hand.

Suggested Read: 17 Best Zoos In India That Every Wildlife Enthusiast Must Add To Their Travel Bucket List!

21. Hogenakkal, Tamil Nadu: Niagara Falls Of India

Image Source

Hogenakkal is one of the best places to visit in Tamil Nadu. It is a waterfall located in the Dharmapuri district of Tamil Nadu. Kaveri river splits into streams of waterfalls making a picturesque scene. The Hogenakkal has water throughout the year and offers basket boat rides, fishing and more. The carbonite rocks, and freshwater fish makes it a perfect place to visit and relax during your vacation.

22. Krishna’s Butter Ball, Mahabalipuram: A Rare Phenomenon

Image Source

Krishna butterball is a big granite boulder that is a natural phenomenon and is a famous tourist attraction. Located in Mahabalipuram, the granite is 6 meters high and 5 meters wide and weighs over 250 tons. The stone has been in the same position since 1200 years. It is believed that at one time in history elephants were employed to move the stone but it did not move. The stone is believed to a ball of butter that was dropped by the god.

Further Read: 8 Fascinating Cities To Visit For The Best India Walking Tours

The Indian nature never ceases to amaze us. There are so many natural wonders in India that are just amazing and worth a visit. Let us know which natural wonder amazed you the most on your next trip to India.
